docs.lead_paragraph: WITH all of the scandals in Connecticut over the past five years, taxpayers are paying room and board at various prisons for officials who have been convicted of crimes while doing their jobs. But even when those officials get out of jail, taxpayers will still be paying tens of thousands of dollars in pension and health care benefits when they retire. The fact is, there is no state law that gives it the option to withhold benefits from state officials convicted of crimes. And especially no law for those simply resigning in disgrace. So John G. Rowland, who resigned as governor on July 1 and is a subject of a federal investigation into gifts he received while in office, will receive $50,000 a year from the state when he turns 55, no matter what the federal government finds. Lawrence Alibozek, Mr. Rowland's former deputy chief of staff who has already been convicted of accepting bribes, including gold coins he buried in his yard, will receive $10,188 a year in retirement benefits and full health coverage. And Joseph P. Ganim, the former mayor of Bridgeport who was convicted of extortion and accepting bribes, decided to take his retirement early, so the city has already begun paying his $11,096 a year pension while he is in prison.

headline.main: Out of a Job, But Paychecks Keep on Coming

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jodi West woke up one Friday in May with a weepy, crusty right eye, she rinsed her face and hoped that it would clear up on its own. By the next morning, the infection had spread to both eyes, and she realized that she would have to see someone about it. But she knew that she would have to be quick: her 7-year-old daughter was dancing in two recitals that day. So they got in the car and drove off, not to a hospital emergency room, but to the Target store in Shoreview, Minn., about 15 minutes from their home in Centerville. There, at a clinic in the store, they went to a kiosk and signed the register. After about five minutes, a nurse practitioner ushered Ms. West, 37, into a tiny examining room. She asked a few questions, examined her eyes, wrote a prescription and sent them on their way. ''It took 20 minutes, tops,'' Ms. West said. ''I wish these clinics had been around when my son was young and getting ear infections all the time.''

headline.main: Next to the Express Checkout, Express Medical Care

docs.lead_paragraph: A PHONE call to the New Jersey Board of Nursing office last year disclosed that there are 106,000 licensed nurses in my state. When I followed that up with the question: ''How many of them are working?'' the answer was a resounding ''Not enough!'' Nationwide, half a million nurses have chosen to work outside their field. From 1996 to 2000 the loss of nurses in the work force increased sevenfold. If that number doesn't sound high to you, just wait until you are lying in a hospital bed waiting for pain medication.

docs.lead_paragraph: Master Sgt. Thomas R. Thigpen was 52 when he fell dead of a heart attack during a touch-football game in Kuwait on March 16 -- a casualty that does not quite fit the standard template of wartime tragedy: the fresh-faced 18-year-old cut down with the promise of a full life ahead. He was not the oldest to die since the invasion of Iraq. That would be Staff Sgt. William D. Chaney, 59, who operated the machine gun in the door of his unit's Black Hawk helicopters -- the same job he performed in Vietnam -- and died after surgery for an intestinal problem. Sgt. Floyd G. Knighten Jr., 55, serving in Kuwait in the same unit as his 21-year-old son, died of heat stroke while driving a Humvee without air-conditioning across the scorching Iraqi desert.

docs.lead_paragraph: SHAREHOLDERS like it when their companies are acquired, because their stocks rise in value. Chief executives like it, too, because their severance agreements kick in. And that means they can become truly, titanically, stupefyingly rich. Wallace R. Barr, the chief executive of Caesars Entertainment, is the latest to line up for his barrel of bucks. Last week, Harrah's announced it would acquire Caesars for $5.2 billion. Thanks to accelerated vesting of options and stock awards, Mr. Barr stands to receive almost $20 million under so-called change-of-control provisions in his contract. And if Mr. Barr resigns from Caesars ''for good reason,'' the contract says, he is entitled to an additional $6.6 million after the two companies merge.

headline.main: No Wonder C.E.O.'s Love Those Mergers

docs.lead_paragraph: To many voters, this election -- for all the talk, the money, the attack ads -- could come down to two words: Iraq and jobs. But there are jobs and there are jobs. Monthly government numbers give only the big picture, not quirky slices of reality. Now Challenger, Gray & Christmas, that tireless compiler of jobs data, suggests there are ''Bush jobs'' and ''Kerry jobs'' -- that certain industries will do better if a certain candidate wins. It expects a Bush victory to favor autos, financial services, timber, drugs and tobacco, while a Kerry presidency would be better for jobs in health care, education, government, home building and insurance.

headline.main: Looking at Jobs And Elections From a New Angle

docs.lead_paragraph: The new policy announced by the federal government last week that enables Medicare to consider paying for obesity treatments may transform the weight-loss field by providing, for the first time, reliable data on methods for losing weight. Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson announced Thursday that Medicare was abandoning a long-held policy that said obesity was not a disease, opening the way for the government to pay for a whole range of possible treatments, from surgery and diets to psychotherapy. But the government also said that to be eligible for coverage, treatments must be proved effective. And to determine whether an obesity treatment works, Medicare says it could end up paying for large studies of the treatment's effectiveness.

headline.main: Weight-Loss Field Awaits Change in Medicare Policy

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of lawyers for people with no medical insurance filed a class-action lawsuit yesterday against New York-Presbyterian, the city's largest hospital group, contending that it victimized patients by overcharging them and failing to provide required charity care. The lawsuit is the latest in a series of complaints filed by the lawyers against hospitals across the country. So far, they have filed suits against 31 nonprofit hospital systems in 17 states.
